habitat_description:
The Central American indigo snake is found in areas extending from southern Texas and Sonora into Mexico and Central America. Populations occur in northwestern South America west of the Andes into northern Venezuela (Conant and Collins 1991; McCranie 1980; Wuster et al. 2001). Campbell (1998) found the elevational range in Guatemala to extend from areas near sea level up to 1900 meters.

The habitat includes various herbaceous wetlands, riparian zones, conifer forest, hardwood forest, grassland, shrubland, chaparral, conifer woodland, and hardwood woodland. This species also occurs in tropical and subtropical wet, moist, and dry forests, edges of forest clear-cut areas, savannas, and mangroves (Campbell 1998; Lee 2000). Its Texas habitat consists of thorn brush woodland and savanna of the coastal plain along riparian corridors, but also in coastal sandhills, limestone desert, and prairies (Tennant 1998). Thus, threats in Texas include habitat destruction and fragmentation, roadkill, wanton killing, and also pet trade collection. There are no major known threats to populations in Mexico (Ernst and Ernst 2003; Tennant 1984).

SW	 - In Texas, associated with thorn brush woodland and savanna of the coastal plain. Also limestone desert and prairies (Tennant 1998).
